results.title: No more yesterdays
results.creator_credit: Douglas Warth, British Pathe and Martin Rolfe
results.brief_description: Ireland today - the modern and traditional elements of Irish life with its new industries and consequent prosperity. The changes which are progressive and varied have brought about a “new look” in an old land, improving the living standards of the people while retaining many of the old ways which we associate with Ireland. Commentary by Wilfrid Thomas.

results.title: No more west
results.creator_credit: Educational Pictures, RKO Radio Pictures and Nick Grinde
results.brief_description: Starring comedian Bert Lahr who played the cowardly lion in the Wizard of Oz with Judy Garland. A comic story set in the wild wild west featuring Bert Lahr as the sheriff who finds himself unwittingly facing court for robbing a bank when he was supposed to be out catching the actual bank robbers.

results.title: No more Hiroshima
results.creator_credit: Jacques Vallee, ONF | NFB and Martin Duckworth
results.brief_description: A documentary film portrait of two survivors of the atomic bomb droped on Hiroshima. They are among the minority of survivors who have decided to risk their careers and marriage prospects by identifying themselves with “Hobusyka”. The film follows them as they travel to New York to represent the Japanese peace movement at the second United Nations Special Session on Disarmament in June 1982. Excellent for senior students.

results.title: No more Hibakusha!
results.creator_credit: Jacques Vallee, ONF | NFB, Martin Duckworth and Audrey Schirmer
results.brief_description: Hibakusha is the Japanese word for the survivors of the American bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. This powerful and moving documentary focuses on a few of the eighty hibakusha who journeyed from Japan to New York in June, 1982, to take part in peace demonstrations held to coincide with the Second United Nations Special Session on Disarmament. They came to urge the nations of the world to prevent nuclear war. Instead of concentrating on the physical suffering of the victims, the film reveals the mental anguish of the hibakusha, who are still haunted by nightmares. Inspired by “Hibakusha”, a book of photographs by Ittetsu Morishita. (Awards: Tokyo, Leipzig)

results.title: No more funerals
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Michelle W
results.brief_description: Michelle is diagnosed with HIV in the early 80’s. She reflects on how treatments have improved over the years and celebrates the fact that she no longer attends as many funerals.

results.title: No maps on my taps
results.brief_description: A tribute to jazz tap dancing as an expression of black heritage and culture through the portraits of three surviving dancers - Sandman Sims, Chuck Green and Bunny Briggs - combined with rare photos and film clips from the thirties, the heyday of tap. Contains B&W sequences.

results.title: No love for Luigi
results.creator_credit: Westall Secondary College and Peter Drummond
results.brief_description: An example of student filmmaking revolving around the subject of racism and intolerance. Follows the story of Luigi, an Italian Australian teenager who is racially attacked by a gang of schoolboys. Luigi’s Australian girlfriend flees the scene of the attack, only to encounter the gang alone some time later. Although the film has no spoken dialogue, this compelling short student film captures the mood of xenophobic Australia in the 60’s.

results.title: No longer alone
results.creator_credit: Terry Ashwood, Associated British-Pathe and Frank Cadman
results.brief_description: Tuition available in Britain for blind children who have additional defects. Several homes, caring for different age groups, are run on the “family” system, seven to a family. Affection is given, confidence built up and each child is taught to fend for themselves to the best of their ability. Other subjects, besides classwork, are handwork, nature study, swimming, and independent outings to nearby towns.
